text:
Welcome to How To Cook That, I'm Ann Reardon and 
this week we are debunking, debunking, debunking!

You guys have sent me heaps more viral videos to 
debunk ... if you want to send me something just

submit the link to me on twitter so that i can 
watch it and check it out. This first one comes

from Oliver and heaps more people sent me this one 
as well but Oliver was first and he is asking does

this work? Basically they take popcorn put it in 
a pan add some chocolate then add oil, stir it up

until the popcorn starts popping put the lid 
on and voila! Chocolate-flavored popcorn.

Well Oliver thinks the chocolate will burn I tend 
to agree but as always let's check it out and see

what happens ... put the corn kernels in the pan 
add the chocolate in the middle just like they did

and then add the oil. Turn it on to heat up 
and stir it until it just starts to pop and

then quickly put the lid on so we don't get 
a mess everywhere wait a few moments and if

you could smell the room right now you would know 
that that is smoke not steam coming off the pan.

Oh gosh I'll put some of the nicer looking 
ones of these in a bowl for Dave to try.

I'm avoiding the ones that look like this 
... totally black. There are plenty of those

let me show you the pan's still got heaps of 
unpopped popcorn kernels down the bottom there

and the chocolate mixture is burnt and stuck to 
the bottom of the pan. 🙅‍♂️ It looks pretty good.

oh that's burnt as ... no 
thank you. Oh that's bad!

We've already debunked a very similar video 
that used Skittles to do the same thing,

so why doesn't this work? Well in this instance 
chocolate will burn at 95 degrees centigrade,

the sugar in the chocolate or in the skittles or 
whatever you're using will burn at 176 degrees

centigrade, and popcorn doesn't pop until 
the kernel reaches 180 degrees centigrade.

so you have to have the oil at least 180 and hold 
it there in order to heat up that kernel enough to

make it pop in the meantime you've then burnt 
the sugar or definitely burnt your chocolate.

So if you really are craving chocolate popcorn 
here's what you can do you need to pop the corn

first separately with no chocolate on it and then 
melt some chocolate and I'm just adding some extra

fat into that to thin it down I'm using cocoa 
butter and then just microwave that to melt it.

Add a couple of handfuls of your popcorn in at 
a time into the chocolate now if you're using

real chocolate like I am it's going to need 
tempering or it's just going to stay sticky

it's not going to set firm so once it's starting 
to cool I'm just adding some more freeze-dried

cocoa butter in here to help it to set. If you're 
using compound chocolate you totally don't have

to worry about that you can skip that step and 
then just spread it out and leave it to set.

Hmmmm. So popcorny so chocolaty, 
delicious! I'll have another 💏

Katie sent in this next video and she says she 
thinks it's 100% fake but the comments seem to

disagree with other people saying it's true, so 
let's check it out. The guy gets some sticky tape

puts it on his head rips it off and then puts that 
under a microscope and shows us all the little

creatures that you can see crawling around on his 
face. Well Katie it is true we do have microscopic

little creatures crawling around on our face 
that we can't even see because they're so small.

Usually if you wanted to see them you would 
use a microscopic slide or scientists would

and some super glue and put it on and rip it 
off so you rip out some hair follicles because

face mites live in the hair follicle they 
eat the sebum around your hair, gross hey!

But if you just put sticky tape on and rip 
it off like that you're not going to get

face mites on there if you put the sticky tap 
on you can get them if you then made it really

dark and you stayed really still for a long time 
because they can come out when you're asleep in

the dark but he didn't do that obviously. There is 
a great channel called Microbe Hunter and he has a

video on how you can actually get some face marks 
so that you can look at them under the microscope

and i'll put a link to his video below because he 
explains it all in detail for you. But that is not

what we're seeing on the tiktok video they're 
not face mites they're completely different,

so what has he shown us is on his face? Well i'm 
no microbiologist but i would say that this one

here is a copepod which is found in all sorts of 
water freshwater, saltwater all over the place

and then this other one here on the left looks a 
bit like hydra and the one in the middle looks to

me like a daphnia or a water flea which lives in 
swamps lakes or ponds. So we can deduct either he

has just come fresh out from swimming in a pond in 
his backyard and is still so wet that he could get

a sample that had water in it and they can still 
swim around or he's totally faked it and yes if

you notice there was one there that i didn't tell 
you what it was because i want you super-smart

people to do your own research and figure out what 
microbe that was that i didn't tell you about.

Okay moving on this next one has been a long time 
in the making i was sent this video six months ago

which shows that you should store onions in a 
stocking and tie a knot and I was sent it by so

many people and it says that they will last for 
up to six months hence why i started filming this

six months ago! So i took some onions and i put 
them into a stocking separating each one with a

knot and then putting another one in but so that 
we had a control i also took some onions that i

bought on the same day from the same store and put 
them into a lined basket and i just stored that

in the cupboard. It's finally been six months so 
let's check out what has happened to these onions.

Let's take them out of the stocking cut them 
all out ... the first one here looks a little

mouldy but it's still firm the other two look 
pretty good. Now the advantage of keeping them

separate like this is if one does get moldy it 
doesn't spread to the other ones. Now for the

ones in the basket well they look very similar to 
me they all look pretty good they're still firm,

now let's cut them open the top row are the ones 
from the stocking and this one that i'm cutting

now was from the basket and they both look fine 
to me. So the moral of the story is onions can

last for a really long time they don't have to 
be stored in a stocking. Storing them separately

does help if one goes off doesn't affect all 
of the rest but you can just spread them out

in a basket you don't need to get a stocking it 
just makes it hard to grab an onion when you want

to cook with it. Now before i move on big thank 
you to everybody who came to the book signing in

Melbourne that was so lovely to meet you all we 
have more book signings coming up in Sydney and

Perth please do check the link below regularly 
for updates to those dates because things keep

shifting around with red zones and restrictions 
and all of that stuff we have to make sure we

stick to what we are allowed to do, so check that 
link below to find out when they are. And when I

was looking for the videos for today the ones 
you'd submitted on Twitter I also saw so many

photos people had shared when they excitedly got 
their cookbook just as excited as I was when I got

mine finally and so what I thought I'd do is run 
another competition so we have 10 Wiltshire prize

packs to give away and they have heaps of baking 
gear that will be great when you're making things

in the book and I'm going to give away prizes 
for the best photos which have the book in it

somewhere. So it doesn't have to just be a zoom 
in of the cover because then they're all going

to look exactly the same so come up with some 
creative ideas for a photo, share that social

media and #crazysweetcreations the name of the 
book so that i can find it. I'm going to give

away two of these prize packs to photos that are 
on Instagram, two to photos that are on TikTok or

videos and two that are on Facebook and two 
that are on YouTube (also 2 on Twitter). So

just hashtag that crazy sweet creations. Okay 
moving on to the next one summer sent me this

video from five-minute crafts that shows you 
how you can tell if your food is organic or not

organic. Now i'm sure you would know organic 
means it's been grown without any additional

chemicals and pesticides and all of those things 
so let's see what they say in this first one

they have some honey and they put it in a bowl add 
some water on top and swirl it around and then the

honey gets this sort of honeycomb type pattern on 
it and they're saying if it gets the pattern it is

organic, if it doesn't get the pattern it is not 
organic. So let's test it out and see what happens

we have lots of great honeys here in 
Australia so just put some honey on a plate

add some water and swirl it around in a circular 
motion and look a honeycomb pattern so does that

mean that my honey is organic? Now this test has 
been around for a long time there were old videos

that said that this was honey showing its "genetic 
memory" of how it was stored in the honeycomb and

that's why it had this pattern when you swirl 
water on it and you could tell if that was pure

honey or if it was impure honey it wouldn't form 
the pattern. Well, it's actually just a load of

rubbish! The pattern that's forming is because of 
the water swirling over it you've got the viscous

honey which can be moved slowly by the water and 
the water that's moving quickly over it and it's

changing the position of the honey in the bowl. I 
can prove that to you by just changing how i swirl

the water, if i swirl the water from side to side 
this would work even better in a square container

but it's going to work in a round one then you can 
see the pattern is now different ... it looks more

like a wave pattern and that's because it is the 
water that is making the pattern on the honey. I

can show you again with just a different liquid 
that's not honey if i use golden syrup which is

definitely not honey it's just man-made using 
sugar and if i swirl that round and round and

round then we end up with the same honeycomb 
pattern, it is not a test of pure honey, it's

not a test of if honey is organic or not. It's 
just, it's not a test it just shows you patterns

you can make using water and a viscous liquid. 
So just totally forget that one. There is an

issue with honey though there was a thing called 
Honeygate about four or five years ago where they

tested samples of all these different 
honeys and found that they had actually been

watered down using other sugar syrups because 
it's a lot cheaper to produce. As you would know

bees go to flowers they go to thousands of flowers 
to get nectar just tiny little bits of nectar from

each flower they bring it back to the hive and 
then they start to digest that in their honey

stomach and then they spit that partially digested 
nectar out and give it to another bee who then

adds more enzymes in their stomach and it keeps 
getting passed from bee to bee until eventually

it goes into one of those little honeycomb cells. 
They then use heat and airflow by fanning their

wings to evaporate that off and just thicken it 
up and then they just cover it with wax on the top

and the enzymes process that nectar and 
we get honey. Now that is quite a big

extensive process if you can just use sugar syrup 
instead that's going to be heaps cheaper. If

you're buying pure honey you want pure honey you 
don't just want to have corn syrup or rice syrup

mixed into it so how can we test to see if you've 
got pure honey? Well there's a new test that's

been developed for honey over the last few years 
because of all of the cheating that was going on

and it uses nuclear magnetic resonance or 
NMR and it doesn't just show if there's

other syrups present it can also show where the 
honey originated from because some honeys are

more highly prized than others like your Manuka 
honey. All of that before was a bit of a mystery

you had to trust what the people said on the 
label but now with this test they can actually

check that it is originating from where it said it 
was originating from. So to find out if the honey

that you're getting at the shops is pure you'd 
need to check if in your country they use this NMR

test to double check any imported honey and honey 
made within the country to make sure it says what

it is if it's not then it's a little hard for you 
to tell you definitely cannot swirl it in water

it's not going to help you. Okay moving on to the 
next one in the same video they say we can test if

butter is organic or not organic by putting it in 
some warm water and stirring it and then it says

that non-organic butter dissolves slowly and 
leaves a greasy surface on the water. Well i

think if you just pause the video and think about 
that you would know that fat doesn't dissolve in

water fat floats to the top that's what it does 
and butter is predominantly fat, you've got some

proteins from the milk and the cream in 
there and that's what's going to make the

water cloudy down the bottom but the fat should 
float to the top that's what it's supposed to do.

I can show you i have three different butters 
here two of them are organic one of them is not

and if I stir them all then you can see that the 
fat indeed floats to the top and they all look

identical. So where did the yellow fat go in their 
video it was there at the beginning granted there

wasn't as much because they put heaps of butter 
in the one and only a little bit in the other one

but if i show you frame by frame you see if you 
can tell where the video has been cut ... there's

not really any reason to cut it there unless you 
are swapping it out so you're either swapping

glasses or you're just taking some of the fat out 
by absorbing it on a paper towel who knows what

they did and the weird thing about this is because 
they're using tests that people can repeat at home

like the honey one but giving people the wrong 
conclusions, people do the honey and go oh wow

this must be true but really you've just 
been given completely wrong information

for the experiment that you're conducting. Okay 
moving on rice is next on their list we can tell

if it's organic according to them by putting 
it in oil and if it's organic it will puff up

and float to the top and if it's not organic it 
will sink to the bottom and if you leave it long

enough it will start to go brown like their's 
has because they have overcooked it there.

So we'll add in the rice that is not organic first 
and you can see contrary to their video it is

popping and puffing up and coming to the top this 
will actually happen whether the rice is organic

or not, brown rice, white rice they'll all do 
it. And now if i put some in that is organic rice

it's not popping it's just sinking to the bottom 
so why is that is there test the wrong way around?

No i just changed another factor in that 
experiment which was the temperature ... you have

to get the oil up to 180 preferably a bit hotter 
degrees centigrade in order for that rice to

pop. If you have it too low which is what i did 
with the organic rice it's just going to sink

to the bottom and sit there unless you increase 
the temperature of that oil it's not going to pop

like that so this is the organic rice and it's 
popped perfectly, this is the non-organic rice

and it's popped perfectly and this is actually 
cooked rice that has been dried in the oven

that goes even more a bit like a Rice Bubble but 
greasy or a prawn cracker more probably but don't

just do straight boiled rice if it's got any water 
in it it's going to just make the oil splatter

everywhere you'll probably get oil burns on you 
so don't do that if you boil your rice and cook it

you then have to spread it out on a tray and dry 
out in a dehydrator until it's completely dry then

you can fry it and you'll get that sort of prawn 
cracker consistency. Moving on next they have

parsley this is an interesting one they say we can 
tell if it's organic or not by looking at it i'm

not quite sure what they're trying to tell us here 
are they saying the shorter the stems are cut it's

organic if it says long stems it's not organic? 
Really you can't tell using this test it's just

not possible it's just a weird test. This video 
just is not good it's not good information stop

watching five minute crafts my goodness. Lesmon 
sent me an article about another girl who was

burnt when she was trying to poach an egg in 
a microwave ... if you didn't watch the last

debunking video we have a whole segment on that 
don't poach eggs in the microwave obviously and

just an update on that ... i have escalated this 
with YouTube with my contact there they've said

obviously the normal way is to report the video 
and if it violates their policies it will be taken

down so i have of course let them know they don't 
have a policy against dangerous hacks, they've got

one for dangerous pranks, dangerous challenges but 
there's nothing for dangerous hacks so it doesn't

violate their policy so it can just stay there! 
I'd love to know if there is a lawyer watching

if someone could sue a platform like youtube or 
facebook or that sort of stuff if they're watching

a how-to video on their platform that's already 
had multiple news stories about it about people

getting injured if someone then followed that 
and it was still on the platform with no warnings

nothing on it could they sue the platform or not? 
I'm not a lawyer so I don't know so if you're a

lawyer watching let me know let us all know in 
the comments we'd love to know. With thanks to

my amazing patrons for all that you do and your 
love and your support I really appreciate you here

is a list of legends right here ... don't forget 
if you have the cookbook please do leave a review

if you haven't got it yet you can go and order 
it from your favorite bookstore it is now

out! It is there in real life which is super 
exciting if you liked this video make sure

you let the algorithm know by liking subscribing, 
turning on notifications, commenting and sharing

make it a great week by being kind to 
others and I'll see you next Friday ❤
